title: 110_s2194
content: National Park Ranger School Partnership Program authorized under Part D of title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program establishes partnerships with National Park Ranger Schools. The Secretary may award grants to local educational agencies for authorized activities in partnership with the National Park Service, including educational programs for K-12 students provided by Park Rangers. The National Park Service may award grants to local educational agencies for educational programs emphasizing science, the environment, natural resources, mathematics, history, and civics. Grants are for a 3-year period with a maximum amount of $25,000. Eligible agencies must be near a National Park Service facility or Research and Learning Center and have a partnership or be capable of partnering. Grants under this program are awarded on a competitive basis using criteria established by the Secretary in collaboration with the National Park Service. Grantees must submit a report at the end of the grant period detailing the number of students participating in the activities funded by the grant. The Secretary, in coordination with the National Park Service, will assess the achievements of students in mathematics, science, and other relevant academic areas under the grant. The report will also include the number of educators involved in the activities and the professional development they received. A report must be submitted within 3 years of the enactment of this section. The Secretary, in coordination with the National Park Service, will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the program, including recommendations on its continuation or expansion. Authorization of appropriations is also amended to provide funding for the National Park Ranger School Partnerships for fiscal years 2008 and beyond. The Act (20 U.S.C. 6301 note) is amended to include provisions for the National Park Ranger School Partnerships. The National Park Ranger School Partnerships program is authorized under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The National Park Service is now eligible for certain programs related to mathematics, science, and traditional American history education services.
